title: 115_hr3077
content: The "Senior Citizens' Freedom to Work Act of 2017" repeals the Retirement Earnings Test. The "Senior Citizens' Freedom to Work Act of 2017" repeals various subsections of the Social Security Act, including redesignating certain subsections and making conforming amendments. The "Senior Citizens' Freedom to Work Act of 2017" repeals and redesignates subsections of the Social Security Act, making conforming amendments to related provisions. The Senior Citizens' Freedom to Work Act of 2017 amends sections of the Social Security Act related to deductions for work and exemptions from reductions based on entitlements to child's insurance benefits. The Senior Citizens' Freedom to Work Act of 2017 makes amendments to sections of the Social Security Act regarding suspension of aliens' benefits, reductions in benefits based on maximum benefits, and penalties for misrepresentations. Amendments are made to penalties for misrepresentations concerning earnings and provisions taking into account earnings in determining benefit computation years under the Social Security Act. Amendments are made to provisions relating to rounding of benefits and defining income for purposes of SSI under the Social Security Act. The term 'wages' for paragraph (1)(A) is defined without certain limitations as to amounts of remuneration specified in section 209. Services not constituting employment under section 210 are deemed employment if remuneration is not included in computing net earnings. The term 'wages' excludes certain payments made to employees or their dependents. The curr_chunk discusses the repeal of deductions on account of work under the Railroad Retirement Program. It involves amending sections of the Railroad Retirement Act of 1974. The amendments to the Railroad Retirement Act of 1974 eliminate deductions related to work under the program, effective for taxable years ending after December 31, 2018.
